instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_TB_CC2: What is USBC_TB_CC2? USBC_TB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power. It is cycling  in between 0V to 5V continuously on all 4 usb-c ports (ampmeter powers on and off).

It has no signs of corrosion nither liquid contact, and client says that it just stoped working.

UB300 diode reading:
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.590
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.588
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.467

UB400 diode reading
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.586
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.585
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.478

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> diode reading:
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.586
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.586
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>= 0.468

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> diode reading:
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.587
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.586
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.475

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> has 0.545 on diode reading
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has 0.382 dioed reading
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> has 0.397 on diode reading

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> has 0.006 on diode reading and 3.7 ohm to ground (seams to be shorted). Can I inject 1V here?

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You can inject even 2V, but may need a thermal cam to detect snall temperature differences.
Remove CPU heatsink first...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

It seams that <CHIP>U8220</CHIP> is the culprit. I don't have a same model donor board. Can I use other board models to use the same component?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<CHIP>U8220</CHIP> seams to be the only component that gets hot but even after removing it, the short remains, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> seams to also be shorted (0.003 in diode reading). <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> also gets hot when injecting 2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>.

I don't have a same model donor board.

Can I use the same components from a different model board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Can you help with the board model. I can't find those components on otehr schematics. Do you know any other model?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Look at "Power FETs" page in other schematics.
You may find chips with different name, but same function.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> now has 0.250 in diode reading, but 0V. The power isen't cycling anymore, but it 's still at 5.12V and 0.26A

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

No it isenÂ´t  recognized in DFU. However, I notice that with the battery conected it pulls 20.5V and 0A from ampmeter, on all USB ports, and without battery connected  only 5.12V and 0.26A

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check if T2 gets all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages, required for DFU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
P1V1SLPS2R_FB is cycling  in between 0V and 0.080V
P1V1SLPS2R_SW0 is cycling  in between 0V and 0.080V
P1V1SLPS2R_SW1 is cycling  in between 0V and 0.080V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P1V8_SLPS2RSW_DFR_R</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE_SOC_PCIEPLL_F</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> seams to have a small spot on it that might be burnt signal.

Shall I replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Compare diode mode on its coils with good board.
Also check if <RESISTOR>R7835</RESISTOR> is burnt.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then no doubt, <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is burnt.

Sorry, I was looking at wrong schematic.
Check <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> instead...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> seams to be ok and has 0 ohm resistance.

After replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> all the doils diode readings are likely the same.

After close inspection, I notice that <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> seams to be a bit blown and is geting a bit hot on thermal cam. I don't have a donor board to it. Do you know other board model that I can use as a donor for <CHIP>U8250</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Check schematics from other models.
You may find it used for other power rails...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I used one from other board model, but the problem still persists...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: If you still have low resistance to ground on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> coils, then bad T2...
